summary: Pepper...and Salt

headline: CD Yields Fail to Increase
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mixed in the latest week.

summary: What's News: World-Wide Top Stories for Jan. 4, 2011

headline: St. John's 61, Georgetown 58
summary: Justin Brownlee's tip-in with 10 seconds left lifts the Red Storm to an upset win.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for Jan. 4, 2010

headline: Treasury to Sell $50 Billion
summary: The offerings comprise $25 billion in four-week bills and $25 billion of 56-day cash-management bills.

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for Jan. 4, 2011

headline: Samsung Group to Invest $38.3 Billion in 2011
summary: South Korea's Samsung Group unveiled an aggressive investment plan for this year of 43.1 trillion won ($38.3 billion), stepping up efforts to move into next-generation technologies.

headline: Navy Removes Captain Over Videos
summary: A top Navy admiral permanently relieved the commander of the USS Enterprise for showing a "profound lack of good judgment" by recording offensive and vulgar videos on a previous tour of duty.

headline: Spanish Judge Summons Commander
summary: A Spanish judge has summoned an Iraqi military commander, who is accused of having directed a 2009 assault on a camp in Iraq holding Iranian opponents of the Tehran government, for questioning over alleged breaches of the Geneva Convention.

headline: FDA Warns Invacare Over Electric Beds
summary: Health regulators issued a warning to Invacare for failing to report and address malfunctions with its electric beds, including electronics that allegedly caught on fire causing injury and death.

headline: Winfrey Network Expects Profit in First Year
summary: Oprah Winfrey's new TV channel OWN expects brisk ad sales to push it into profitability during its first year on the air, the finance chief of co-owner Discovery Communications said.

headline: FDIC Goes After Former Bank Executives
summary: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. said it is seeking to recover $2.5 billion by suing former executives of failed U.S. banks.

headline: Stocks Tick Higher After Fed Minutes
summary: Blue-chip stocks tacked on a second straight session of gains this year, boosted by encouraging economic data and relief over a quiet set of minutes from the Federal Reserve's last meeting.

headline: Financial Briefing Book: Jan. 5
summary: Financial Briefing Book: Jan. 5

headline: Court Deals Setback to Hyundai Group
summary: A Korean court rejected Hyundai Group's attempt to salvage its bid for a controlling stake in Hyundai Engineering & Construction, paving the way for rival bidder Hyundai Motor Group to acquire the builder's shares.

headline: AIG Says Nan Shan Unit Fetched $3 Billion Bid
summary: American International Group told regulators in November it had been offered as much as $3 billion for the Taiwanese life-insurance unit it has been trying to sell to help repay its government bailout.

headline: CES Notebook
summary: H-P skips the tablet mania, Netflix comes to remote controls and other highlights ahead of the CES trade show.

headline: Floods May Cut Off Australian City
summary: Rising water levels in northeastern Australia threatened to cut off the city of Rockhampton in Queensland state, while the U.S. government offered aid to some 200,000 people affected by the record floods.

headline: BP's Resurgence Helps Push FTSE Up 1.9%
summary: European stocks generally rose Tuesday, led by the oil-and-gas sector after British oil giant BP soared to a six-month high.

headline: Options Traders Buck Bearish Moment for Family Dollar, Supervalu
summary: Options traders acting on the eve of budget retailer Family Dollar Stores' quarterly results seemed confident in the stock's prospects even as Wall Street was cautious. Ditto for traders in Supervalu stock, which was dented by a supermarket-sector downgrade.

headline: U.S. Proposes Changes To Comply With WTO Rulings
summary: The Commerce Department, hoping to head off retaliation by the European Union, Japan, and other trading partners has proposed ending a controversial method of calculating penalties on trade dumping cases.

headline: Many Defibrillator Patients Not Meeting Guidelines
summary: A study of nearly 112,000 implantable-defibrillator patients said more than one in five didn't meet medical guidelines for getting the expensive devices, and in some cases may not have needed one.

headline: GE Arm Leads Corporate Sales
summary: GE Capital, the lending arm of General Electric Co., sold a $6 billion four-part bond, leading a wave of investment-grade deals totaling nearly $18 billion from almost a dozen corporate borrowers.

headline: Wheeler Last Seen in Wilmington
summary: A Vietnam War veteran and former aide to three U.S. presidents who was found slain in a Wilmington, Del., garbage dump was last seen alive in the city's business district a day before his body was discovered.

headline: Red Roof's Ordeal Nears an End
summary: Red Roof Inn Inc.'s debt saga appears to be coming to an end, with the voluntary forfeiture of 127 of its hotels to holders of their mortgages.

Goldman Sachs was smart to get its tentacles into Facebook early. According to Dealogic, Goldman has had an equity investment in 17 companies that have gone public since 2005. It collected fees as an IPO underwriter from 15 of them.

headline: A Fast, Casual Burger
summary: The Counter, a California-based burger franchise that recently set up shop in Times Square, offers a variety of options: some 312,120 different burger combinations.

headline: Autonomy Global Posts Gains
summary: Hedge-fund manager Robert Gibbins's flagship $1.7 billion Autonomy Global Macro Fund recorded a net 26.3% gain last year.

headline: Polygon Fund Logs 28.4% Gain
summary: London-based Polygon Investment Partners' Polygon European Equity Opportunity Fund posted a net gain of 28.4% last year

headline: Crude Settles Below $90
summary: Traders appear to be looking to lock in profits after steady gains in oil in recent months.

headline: Gold Prices Fall 3.1%
summary: Gold retreated below $1,400 as investors locked in gains made over the past two weeks.

headline: As USDA Assesses Florida Freeze, OJ Futures Get Pressured
summary: Orange-juice prices may surge and the increases could be passed on to consumers as the U.S. government assesses the damage from the coldest December on record for Florida's citrus-growing areas.

headline: Sinovel to Raise Up to $1.4 Billion
summary: Sinovel Wind plans to raise up to $1.44 billion in an IPO ahead of a Shanghai listing, bucking the trend of China's wind power firms listing in Hong Kong.

headline: Gannett Imposes One-Week Furlough
summary: Gannett Co. said all non-union employees in its U.S. community newspaper division will be required to take a one-week furlough during the first quarter due to continuing revenue declines.

headline: Confidence Falters in Troubled EU Economies
summary: Confidence in Ireland and Greece has fallen steeply, according to an annual survey that measures business sentiment at the beginning of 2011.

headline: Shares of Motorola's Successors Jump
summary: Shares of Motorola Mobility Holdings and Motorola Solutions jumped Tuesday as Motorola Inc. officially split into the two entities.

headline: A Shaky Power Center
summary: The U.S. Senate is the last bastion of Democratic power in the new Congress, but it will be a sometimes-shaky platform for President Barack Obama's agenda as his party navigates political currents that have turned sharply against them. Meet some of the key players.

headline: Tax Deadline Pushed Back Three Days
summary: The IRS said taxpayers will have until Monday, April 18, to file their 2010 tax returns because of a holiday being observed in the capital on April 15.

headline: Loomis Sayles Fund Gets Aggressive
summary: Managers of the Loomis Sayles Core Plus Bond fund have dropped their defensive stance for a more aggressive approach.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, Sudan readies for a referendum vote, a poor child eats by a roadside in India, DNA clears a Texas man after 30 years and more.

headline: Study Points to Retirement Challenges in Canada
summary: Will Canadians be able to maintain their living standards when they retire? Probably not, according to a recent study.

headline: Harrisburg Workers Face  a New Paycheck Threat
summary: Employees in the distressed capital city Harrisburg, Pa., once again find their paychecks this week in jeopardy—this time because of a disagreement over protocol.

headline: Student Loan Default Recovery Rates High
summary: After collection expenses, the U.S. Department of Education expects to recover 85% of defaulted federal loan dollars. Banks, on the other hand, often retrieve less than 10 cents on the dollar from credit card defaults.

headline: Och-Ziff Assets Stay at $27.6 Billion
summary: Och-Ziff Capital Management's assets under management remained unchanged in December, despite modest performance gains recorded at its four funds. But they were up 19% on the year.

headline: Banks Drag India Shares Down
summary: Indian shares snapped a four-day positive run to close lower Tuesday after a volatile session, as fears of a rise in interest rates sparked a selloff in banking shares.

headline: Oberthur Still Interested in De La Rue
summary: Oberthur sought reassurances from acquisition target De La Rue about the impact on its business and reputation of paper-production irregularities.

headline: How Australian Floods Weigh on U.S. Coal Prices
summary: Australia supplies about 3% of the world's thermal coal, which is used to generate electricity. But as a top exporter of the fuel, even a small disruption can affect prices around the world.

headline: Bankers, Investors Eye Companies' Cash
summary: The stage is set for a tussle this year between shareholders and investment bankers over how to best put to use the more than $2 trillion of cash sitting on U.S. and European companies' balance sheets.

headline: Dell to Buy Security Provider SecureWorks
summary: Dell agreed to acquire information-security company SecureWorks, as the computer maker continues its expansion into providing technology services.

headline: Eyes Turn Skyward for Solar Eclipse
summary: A partial solar eclipse that began over the Mideast extended across much of Europe Tuesday.

headline: European Stocks Rise; BP Hits 6-Month High
summary: European stocks were generally higher, led by the oil-and-gas sector after British oil giant BP soared to a six-month high.

headline: Piraeus: Discount Is 'Customary'
summary: Greece's Piraeus Bank defended its decision to offer new shares at a deep discount in its €807 million rights issue, saying such a move was "customary" in volatile times and that the terms were backed by a significant percentage of shareholders.

headline: Recovery Skips Reinsurers
summary: Reinsurance companies have already faced average price falls of 5% to 10% from crucial Jan. 1 contract renewals. Pressure will rise for more buybacks and higher dividends, but investors shouldn't expect a windfall this year.

headline: U.K. Data Broadly Positive
summary: U.K. manufacturing expanded at its fastest rate in 16 years in December, adding weight to indications that the country's economic recovery is picking up pace. But other figures provided a more cautious view.

headline: Macy's to Expand Websites
summary: Macy's expects to add about 725 new positions over the next two years as it looks to expand its website offerings.

headline: California Fleeing
summary: Governors across the country adopt a new economic strategy: Raid California for its businesses.

headline: Global M&A Raised $2.4 Trillion in 2010
summary: Global merger and acquisition deals raised $2.4 trillion, up 23% from 2009 and the strongest full-year period since 2008. A record-setting one-third of those deals were in emerging markets.

headline: GE Capital, Others Plan Major Debt Deals
summary: GE Capital, the lending arm of General Electric Co., is planning a benchmark-sized multi-tranche bond offering for sale Tuesday, and other companies are following suit.

headline: Japan's Kan Urges Talks on Raising Tax
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Naoto Kan said he wants to begin talks with the country's opposition parties on raising the nation's consumption tax, in a move that could further erode public approval of the government.

headline: Factory Orders Increase
summary: U.S. factory goods orders rose 0.7% in November, giving another indication of solid momentum in manufacturing amid a growing economy.

headline: Man Gets 15 Years for 1968 Hijacking
summary: A U.S. citizen who hijacked a flight from New York's John F. Kennedy International Airport in 1968 and fled to Cuba was sentenced to 15 years in prison

headline: Garuda Plans $500 Million IPO
summary: Indonesian flag carrier Garuda began pre-marketing for an initial public offering in Jakarta.

headline: Asda Chairman Steps Down
summary: Andy Bond has stepped down as chairman of Wal-Mart's U.K. supermarket chain Asda with effect from the beginning of the year, the company said.

headline: U.K. Broad Money Supply Picks Up
summary: The Bank of England's preferred measure of broad money supply picked up in November although the pace remained weak, underscoring the likelihood that the central bank will keep policy on hold.

headline: Asia Climbs; Seoul Hits New Record
summary: Asian stock markets were supported by Wall Street's gains, with South Korean shares hitting a new record and Chinese stocks posting solid gains in the first trading session of 2011.

headline: Former CapitaMall Trust CEO Plans IPO
summary: Pua Seck Guan, CapitaMall Trust's former chief executive, plans to raise about $778.5 million through a Singapore initial public offering of a real estate investment trust.

headline: Petrobras Eyeing Galp Stake
summary: Brazilian state-run oil company Petroleo Brasileiro confirmed that it's evaluating buying all of Italian oil major Eni's 33.34% stake in Portuguese energy company Galp Energia.

headline: GM's China Sales Top Two Million
summary: GM's sales rose 29% in China last year, making the company the first foreign auto maker to surpass the two-million-unit mark. Toyota's China sales increased 19%.

headline: Pakistani Governor Dead in Shooting
summary: A leading politician from Pakistan's ruling party who had recently spoken out against the country's controversial blasphemy laws was killed Tuesday by a member of his security detail in an upscale market in Islamabad, his political secretary and police said.

headline: Cairn Keeps Focus on Greenland
summary: Cairn Energy said it has contracted two vessels to drill up to four oil and gas exploration wells this year offshore Greenland, following the drilling of three wells in summer 2010 which provided mixed results.

headline: Reinsurance Rates Fall
summary: Despite a flurry of natural disasters in the first half of 2010, reinsurance companies charged about 5% to 10% less as they negotiated new catastrophe coverage that kicked in on Jan. 1.

headline: Seoul's Pension Service to Form Private-Equity Fund
summary: South Korea's national pension manager plans to jointly invest with domestic conglomerates in overseas businesses, as the world's fourth-largest pension fund seeks to diversify its portfolio.

headline: India Hungry for Foreign Coal Assets
summary: As the country prepares to tackle competition from countries such as China to secure energy resources globally, India is working on a policy that will allow state-run companies to acquire coal assets abroad faster, said Coal Minister Sriprakash Jaiswal.

headline: Goldman Clients Jockey for Shot at Facebook Shares
summary: Wealthy clients of Goldman Sachs began jockeying for a piece of the deal struck by the securities firm to invest in social-networking company Facebook.

headline: Fresenius Buys Euromedic Unit
summary: Euromedic has sold its kidney dialysis division to Fresenius Medical Care for €485 million ($648.5 million), the companies said.

headline: Pfizer, Santaris Expand Collaboration Pact
summary: Pfizer has expanded its collaboration with drug maker Santaris Pharma, agreeing to a development and commercialization pact that could see it paying as much as $600 million.

headline: Japanese Yields Jump
summary: Japanese government bond yields climbed on the first trading session of 2011, hurt by a jump in domestic share prices and higher U.S. yields.

headline: Australia Hoping to Stem English Flood of Runs
summary: Wayward bowling from the Australians just give England the edge at the close of play on the second day of the final Ashes test in Sydney, writes Michael Atherton.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Probe Ends
summary: Prosecutors in Bonn, Germany dropped an investigation against Deutsche Telekom AG chief René Obermann for alleged bribery and coercion of government officials in Macedonia and Montenegro.

headline: San Miguel Planning Logistics Complex in Manila
summary: San Miguel said that it is planning to build an integrated logistics complex within Manila's North Harbor together with its subsidiaries and that it has earmarked an initial budget of about $458 million for the project.

headline: Environment Vs. Business in India
summary: Under Environment Minister Jairam Ramesh, India has been taking a tougher stand on environmental reviews of several industrialization projects, many of which are seen as key to further economic growth.

headline: Canada's Competitive Edge
summary: A warmer climate for capital up north.

headline: Deep-Water Drilling Path Clears
summary: Deep-water drilling in the Gulf could resume within weeks under a policy announced by the Obama administration, which has come under  criticism from the oil industry and politicians over the impact of the drilling halt.

headline: Sprint Takes Price Fight to 4G
summary: Sprint Nextel, the country's third-largest carrier rolled out a new fourth-generation smartphone, the HTC EVO Shift, for $149.

headline: Reform Banking to Tame China's Real-Estate Mania
summary: A reader responds to Hugo Restall's Wall Street Journal op-ed, "A Frenzy in China."

headline: Two Sides to Every Photo
summary: Why do so many photography critics dislike photography? Author and NYU professor Susie Linfield chats about her new book "The Cruel Radiance: Photography and Political Violence."

headline: BofA Pays for Soured Loans
summary: Bank of America agreed to pay $2.8 billion to Fannie and Freddie over Countrywide mortgages.

headline: Rally in Commodities Stalls
summary: The year-end rally that drove some commodities to multiyear highs stalled on Tuesday, sending gold to the worst price decline in six months and wiping out recent advances in everything from silver to oil to sugar.

headline: U.S. Car Business in Major Shift
summary: U.S. auto sales rose 11% in December, capping a year that suggests the industry is on the verge of one of the most dramatic shifts in its history.

headline: Contenders for RNC Post Snipe at Steele
summary: Candidates to head the Republican National Committee took shots at its embattled chairman, Michael Steele, at a packed debate less than two weeks before committee members will pick a leader heading into the 2012 election.

headline: Record-Breaking Week on Broadway
summary: Broadway enjoyed what was likely the highest-grossing week in its history this holiday season, with at least three shows reporting the highest one-week dollar figures in their respective runs on the Great White Way.

headline: Two Executives Leave Borders
summary: Borders Group announced the departure of two top executives. But the bookseller got a vote of confidence when one distributor said it will continue to ship books, despite the retailer's wobbly finances.

headline: Cowboys, Gangsters Aim at Each Other
summary: Practical shooters have long dressed up as cowboys as part of the firing-range sport. Now a group is wearing zoot suits and using Tommy guns to recreate Prohibition era gangsters and G-Men.

headline: Democrats Take Aim at Filibusters
summary: Democrats frustrated over the use of filibusters to slow or block legislation say they will push for procedural changes on Wednesday, when the new Senate convenes.

headline: Battered Europe Has the Strength to Merge
summary: The mergers-and-acquisitions market in Europe continued its slow recovery in the fourth quarter, and most investment bankers predict a continued improvement in 2011 despite persistent concerns over Europe's financial health.

headline: Indian Police Probe Citi, Pandit
summary: The Indian police registered a case against top Citigroup officials, including Chief Executive Vikram Pandit, in connection with a estimated $67.2 million alleged fraud at a Citibank branch in a New Delhi suburb.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: The Best and Worst Jobs
summary: Software engineers land the top spot in a new ranking of the best and worst occupations in the U.S. See what else made the list.

summary: This restored 18th century home near Marseilles, France, has nearly 200 hectares of vineyards, woodland and olive groves.

headline: Facebook: Public Friend No. 1
summary: Mark Zuckerberg has indicated little interest in taking Facebook public. But taking an investment from Goldman Sachs and Digital Sky Technologies sets it on a clear road to that outcome.

headline: Spicing Up a Winter Wardrobe
summary: In Tricks of the Trade, designer Cynthia Rowley says there are many ways to spice up your look—even in the dull days of January.

headline: A Shaky Power Center
summary: The U.S. Senate is the last bastion of Democratic power in the new Congress, but it will be a sometimes-shaky platform for President Barack Obama's agenda as his party navigates political currents that have turned sharply against them. Meet some of the key players.

headline: Shell to Face Nigeria Grilling
summary: Royal Dutch Shell will this month be grilled by Dutch lawmakers for the first time over its operations in the Niger Delta, reflecting growing concern about environmental damage from oil spills in west Africa.

headline: Bruce Ackerman: Filibuster Reform Both Parties Can Agree On
summary: Presidents should get a speedy up-or-down vote on executive branch nominees.

headline: China Signals Interest in Spain Debt
summary: China supports Spain's economic reforms and will continue buying its government debt, Chinese Vice Premier Li Keqiang wrote in a newspaper on the eve of a visit to Spain.

headline: BofA's Premature Mortgage Celebration
summary: Bank of America certainly started the New Year with a bang—soothing fears about the cost of repurchasing soured mortgages it sold to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. Investors, who drove the stock up more than 6%, shouldn't party too hard.

headline: Fresh Signs of Life in Office Market
summary: The amount of occupied U.S. office space increased for the first time in nearly three years during the fourth quarter of 2010 as more companies that had been postponing real-estate decisions got back into the leasing market.

headline: FDA Prepares to Enact Food-Safety Law
summary: The FDA is preparing to enact provisions of the new food-safety bill that was passed by Congress in the waning days of 2010 and is expected to be signed into law Tuesday.

headline: Stephens: Egypt's Prison of Hate
summary: You know a country is in trouble when it blames shark attacks on the Mossad.

headline: Don't Kick the People Who Create Our Jobs
summary: Time and again it is said that "Liberal Democrats believe higher earners have benefited the most from the economy's growth in the last 20 year" ("Estate-Tax Passage Is Likely," U.S. News, Dec. 9). Isn't it more likely that the "higher earners" were the cause of the economy's growth in the last 20 years?

headline: Auto-Bailout Planner in Line for Post
summary: President Obama is considering naming one of the architects of the Detroit auto bailout, Ron Bloom, to a new manufacturing policy post at the White House.

headline: All the President's Men
summary: A new monument in Philadelphia remembers the nine slaves kept by George Washington at the President's House.

headline: The Mayor Wants You to Lose Weight
summary: Frustrated with the high cost of health care, a number of communities around the country are taking new steps to encourage citizens to improve their health.

headline: Traders Brace for Action in Alcoa and GM
summary: In the options market Monday, Alcoa and General Motors each saw notable bullish activity.

headline: Hero Group Exec Arrested in Citi Fraud Case
summary: An executive with a Hero Group firm has been arrested as the investigation into a $67 million alleged fraud at a Citibank branch on the outskirts of New Delhi widened.

headline: Two Enemies Who Need Each Other
summary: The Christmas truce is over and the battle between the financial markets and the euro-zone managers resumes.

headline: Abheek Bhattacharya: India's Military Muddle
summary: Even on occasions when India has the personnel and equipment, it lacks the will power to deploy them, a new book on India's military says.

headline: Cuomo Targeting Medicaid Spending
summary: Gov. Andrew Cuomo wants to reduce the state's Medicaid spending by billions of dollars, exceeding the size of cuts to the program proposed in past years.

headline: Business Watch
summary: Here is a selection of business news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Navy Weighs Firing Chief Over Videos
summary: The Navy will likely remove the commander of the USS Enterprise from his post after bawdy videos in which he denigrated gays and made other vulgar references became public.

headline: Roger Pilon: Congress Rediscovers the Constitution
summary: The House Republican majority has said it will require members to cite the specific authority for any bill they introduce.

headline: Jets, Favre Face Lawsuit by Therapists
summary: Two former part-time employees of the Jets filed a lawsuit in New York Supreme Court alleging that their complaints about sexually suggestive text messages from former quarterback Brett Favre cost them their jobs with the team.

headline: Unsnarling the Penn Choke Point
summary: All NJ Transit trains travel on two tracks to and from Penn Station -- so even small glitches can delay hundreds of trains. It is Kevin O'Connor's job to keep things moving.

headline: 'Dark Pools' Pick Up Stock-Trading Share
summary: Private markets accounted for a record 1 in 3 U.S. stock trades last month as the country's four largest stock-exchange groups continued to lose market share, according to data compiled by Raymond James Financial.

headline: Microsoft Alliance With Intel Shows Age
summary: The tech industry's most lucrative partnership—the alliance between Microsoft and Intel—is coming to a day of reckoning. Sales of gadgets using rival technologies are taking off, pushing the two to go their separate ways.

headline: Dark Clouds Over Brightening Economic Skies
summary: As 2011 kicks off, the U.S. economy looks the healthiest it has in years, but that doesn't mean the recovery won't face strong headwinds.

headline: Why Have White-Collar Unions?
summary: Regarding the letter from Linda Hamilton, president of the Minnesota Nurses Association (Dec. 20): I never fail to be baffled as to why a group of individuals who have college degrees need collective bargaining.

headline: Australia's Floods Exact Economic Toll
summary: Flooding in Australia's coal-rich state of Queensland is expected to worsen, adding to the disaster's economic impact. Some residents are beset with contaminated water and are battling snakes seeking dry ground.

headline: Fiat Could Boost Chrysler Stake
summary: Fiat's CEO said he doesn't plan to merge operations with Chrysler, but noted the Italian firm could lift its stake in the U.S. auto maker if Chrysler returns to the stock market.

headline: Chips Makers Aim Beyond Computers
summary: Chip makers, already competing to get their products into computers and phones, are preparing for a wider battle as more devices connect to the Internet.

headline: Data Dent Dollar's Gains
summary: The dollar gave up most of its early gains against the euro Monday after encouraging U.S. economic data sent traders into riskier, higher-yielding assets.

headline: Are Americans Wusses or Fond of Trash Talk?
summary: Wimp. Sissy. Wuss. They're the words trotted out when talking about the whiniest, most-fearful, most-paranoid aspects of our culture today. Why are these such potent accusations in America?

headline: ETFs Try to Outdo Money Funds
summary: A Pimco fund aims to provide a better return than money-market funds at a time of strikingly low yields.

headline: Bondholders Rattled by Prepayment Covenants
summary: Bond markets remain so frothy that corporate-bond buyers aren't worried they won't get paid; they are worried about getting paid too soon.

headline: Getting in Shape the Military Way
summary: Kristen Silverman, the chief operating officer of a private resort in the Bahamas, gets in shape with boot-camp fitness classes.

headline: McGurn: Labor's Coming Class War
summary: Private-sector union workers begin to notice that their job prospects are at risk from public-employee union contracts.

headline: Does Elvis Still Matter?
summary: "The Complete Elvis Presley Masters" serves as a reminder of how vital was the early music of Presley, but it doesn't help much in answering the question of his present relevance as a musician.

headline: Cash Keeps Facebook Private
summary: Facebook has raised $500 million from Goldman Sachs and a Russian investment firm, building a war chest that will allow it to stay private longer.

headline: The EPA's War on Texas
summary: The agency punishes the state for challenging its anticarbon rules.

headline: Emanuele Ottolenghi: Punish Iran's Human-Rights Abusers
summary: While going after the regime's torturers, Western democracies should also give voice to their victims.

headline: The Real World Consequences of Oregon's Tax Increase
summary: The failure of Oregon's recent punitive tax on high income individuals to raise anything close to the projected additional revenue is no surprise based on the experience of other taxing entities, let alone on common sense.

headline: American Airlines' Dogfight With Expedia
summary: Vodka distillers use any gimmick, from fancy bottles to endorsements from Diddy, to transform a commodity into a premium product. In its spat with Expedia and Orbitz, it looks like American Airlines is trying to do the same for plane tickets.

headline: Investigators Urge Pipeline Measures
summary: Federal investigators are urging PG&E to identify all of its gas transmission lines that haven't undergone testing for safe operating pressures in the wake of a deadly pipeline blast last year.
